author: Samantha Newsam
title: From Farrer to future diplomat: Bailey's journey
text:
Bailey Bower is a young man with the world - literally, he hopes - at his feet.
The [Farrer](https://www.northerndailyleader.com.au/story/8774438/robotics-challenge-sparks-creativity-at-farrer-high-school/) student's dream career is to be a diplomat, preferably somewhere in Europe.
"You get to travel the world and get to be almost a spokesperson for your country, which would be a cool experience," he said.
The Year 11 student was speaking with [The Leader](https://www.northerndailyleader.com.au/) after returning from the NSW Schools Constitutional Convention.
The event brought together almost 100 Year 11 students from across the state to engage in discussions about democracy and the Constitution.
Held at Parliament House in Sydney, following a tour of the house and talks from the president of the Legislative Council of NSW Ben Franklin, and University of Sydney Professor Emerita of Constitutional Law Anne Twomey, students then participated in a series of workshops and discussions covering different topics.
For Bailey, the latter pushed him out of his comfort zone.
"It was a bit daunting," he said of having to express his opinions in such an open environment.
"I like to be sort of quiet and not be very argumentative (his parents might say otherwise, he added)."
Be that as it may, his peers must have liked what he had to say.
At the end of the day, he was selected as one of the four students to attend the national convention in Canberra in March 2025.
The convention will run for three days rather than one, as the state event was. The itinerary includes a visit to Old Parliament House and dinner at the Press Club.
They'll also meet with various politicians, including possibly the Prime Minister.
"I'm sure I'll probably be way more nervous when I actually get there, but I'm also pretty excited," he said.
"We get to meet some cool people."
It promises to be a valuable experience as he looks to pursue a career in the political field.
Not in the front-and-centre sense, his interest is more in the behind-the-scenes work, particularly the geopolitical area.
Post-school he hopes to do a double degree in law and international relations.
That hasn't, though, always been the plan.
While he's long been fascinated by politics and history, this time last year, he was leaning more towards environmental science.
But, after taking legal studies as a subject for Year 11, he found a genuine interest in it.
"Even the stuff that was boring, I was really enjoying, so I thought this is something that I really want to lock in a do for a fair while after school," he said.
Bailey was joined in Sydney by [Oxley High's ](https://www.northerndailyleader.com.au/story/8826802/oxley-high-2024-year-12-graduates-celebrate-milestone-night/)Emily Wood.
"It was a massive opportunity to broaden my horizons and have really informed discussions with like-minded people," she said of the experience.
She also enjoyed learning more about the Constitution, which isn't covered much in the legal studies syllabus.
It was also a good opportunity to "get more insight" into the law field.
Like Bailey, she is hoping to study law when she graduates.

author: AFP
title: 158 muertos y decenas de desaparecidos en las inundaciones del siglo en Espa√±a
text:
Las peores inundaciones en m√°s de medio siglo en Espa√±a dejaron al menos 158 muertos y decenas de desaparecidos, informaron este jueves las autoridades que siguen buscando v√≠ctimas en poblaciones arrasadas por el agua y el lodo.
¬´En este momento, y de forma provisional, la cifra de v√≠ctimas mortales asciende a 155 personas¬ª, indicaron en un comunicado este jueves en la tarde los servicios de emergencia de la regi√≥n de Valencia, la m√°s afectada por las lluvias torrenciales entre martes y mi√©rcoles.
Otras dos personas fallecieron en la vecina Castilla-La Mancha y una m√°s en Andaluc√≠a.
A ese total se suman ¬´decenas y decenas de desaparecidos¬ª, indic√≥ el ministro de Pol√≠tica Territorial , √Ångel V√≠ctor Torres, en rueda de prensa el jueves en la noche.
Esto hace temer que siga aumentando el saldo, que ya es el m√°s elevado por un desastre meteorol√≥gico en Espa√±a desde las inundaciones que dejaron 300 fallecidos en octubre de 1973.
La emergencia meteorol√≥gica ¬´contin√∫a¬ª, advirti√≥ este jueves en una visita a la regi√≥n el presidente del gobierno, Pedro S√°nchez, quien pidi√≥ a los habitantes de Valencia quedarse ¬´en casa¬ª para ¬´salvaguardar¬ª vidas.
La agencia estatal de meteorolog√≠a, la Aemet, decret√≥ el jueves en la ma√±ana alerta roja por lluvias en Castell√≥n, zona de la Comunidad Valenciana al norte de las partes m√°s afectadas, pero en la tarde rebaj√≥ su peligrosidad a naranja.
La Comunitat Valenciana tiene desde el primer momento todos los recursos del Estado a su disposici√≥n.
‚ûïDisponible toda la capacidad de la UME para:
üó∫Ô∏è Llegar a todos los pueblos
üöÅ Log√≠stica
üööAbastecimiento
üõ£Ô∏èInfraestructuras
ü´ÇAtenci√≥n a v√≠ctimas pic.twitter.com/LiU8n5rWvZ
‚Äî √Ångel V√≠ctor Torres P√©rez (@avtorresp) October 31, 2024
Afectados por inundaciones necesitan ayuda Mientras las labores de b√∫squeda continuaban, en localidades como Paiporta, una de las afectadas por las riadas que se formaron el martes en la noche, los habitantes intentaban limpiar las calles, cubiertas todav√≠a de barro y de autom√≥viles arrastrados por la corriente.
En Paiporta, localidad de 25.000 habitantes en la periferia sur de la ciudad de Valencia donde murieron m√°s de 60 personas, no queda ning√∫n ¬´comercio en pie (‚Ä¶) Necesitamos ayuda humanitaria con alimentos, con agua, porque no hay agua en las casas¬ª, dijo a la AFP David Romero, m√∫sico de 27 a√±os de edad.
El ministro Torres anunci√≥ que a partir del viernes el ej√©rcito, que hasta ahora participaba en labores de rescate, comenzar√° a colaborar en distribuci√≥n de suministros.
Tras haber decretado tres d√≠as de luto, Pedro S√°nchez anunci√≥ que la regi√≥n ser√° declarada zona catastr√≥fica para agilizar recursos destinados a la reconstrucci√≥n.
El presidente de la Comunidad Valenciana, Carlos Maz√≥n, ya hab√≠a informado de una ayuda de emergencia de 250 millones de euros (270 millones de d√≥lares) para los afectados.
El jueves, miles de valencianos continuaban privados de electricidad, seg√∫n los servicios de emergencias.
Muchas carreteras segu√≠an cortadas, algunas por la acumulaci√≥n de veh√≠culos arrastrados por el agua, cubiertos de barro y escombros. El tren de alta velocidad entre Madrid y Valencia permanecer√° paralizado unas tres semanas m√°s, seg√∫n el Ministerio de Transportes.
Lluvias m√°s ¬´destructivas¬ª ¬´No pensaba vivir esto nunca¬ª, declar√≥ a AFP Eliu S√°nchez, habitante de Sedav√≠, municipio de 10.000 habitantes devastado por las intemperies, que vivi√≥ el martes una noche de pesadilla.
¬´Vimos a un joven que estaba en el descampado y se lo llev√≥ la corriente¬ª, cont√≥ el electricista de 32 a√±os de edad. ¬´Estaba encima del coche, se ve que intent√≥ saltar a otro, pero se lo llev√≥¬ª.
Seg√∫n la Aemet, el martes en la noche y el mi√©rcoles en la madrugada poblaciones de la regi√≥n recibieron m√°s de 300 litros de agua por metro2 (cerca de 300 mm). El m√°ximo se registr√≥ en el peque√±o pueblo de Chiva, con 491 mm, el equivalente ¬´a un a√±o de precipitaciones¬ª, precis√≥.
La prensa espa√±ola, que describe el episodio como las ¬´inundaciones del siglo¬ª, cuestiona la reacci√≥n de las autoridades: el mensaje de alerta del servicio de protecci√≥n civil se envi√≥ el martes a las 20H00, pese a que la Aemet hab√≠a declarado desde la ma√±ana la alerta roja.
La Comunidad Valenciana y la costa mediterr√°nea espa√±ola en general sufren regularmente en el oto√±o boreal el fen√≥meno de la ¬´gota fr√≠a¬ª, depresi√≥n aislada en elevada altitud que provoca lluvias repentinas y extremadamente violentas.
Los cient√≠ficos advierten desde hace a√±os que fen√≥menos meteorol√≥gicos extremos como olas de calor o este tipo de tormentas son cada vez m√°s frecuentes e intensos por el cambio clim√°tico.
Las lluvias torrenciales que azotaron Espa√±a fueron 12% m√°s intensas y dos veces m√°s probables que cuando el clima no se hab√≠a calentado, estimaron los cient√≠ficos de la red World Weather Attribution, que eval√∫a la relaci√≥n entre los fen√≥menos meteorol√≥gicos extremos y el cambio clim√°tico.

author: @Aaron_Smith79
title: Vacant Deloraine lot to be revitalised into a new community hub | The Examiner | Launceston, TAS
text: After a lot in the heart of Deloraine was left vacant for more than a decade, one local group wants to give it back to the community. Once home to the Deloraine Take Away and Coffee Shop, 33-35 Emu Bay Road has been an empty space in the busiest part of town since 2010. That could soon change as Arts Deloraine looks to lease the property for its 'Pocket Park Project'. Committee member Louise Middleton said the group planned to create an urban community hub with seating and stages for live performances. "People can come and sit down and have their coffee with friends or be entertained," she said. "We'll be calling on a lot of organisations that already exist, like the Deloraine Big Band, the Dramatic Society, the Lions Club can come and sell lottery tickets here. "It's going to be open to people's imagination. We can have buskers, I was even thinking we could have a chalk drawing competition." Among the group's "endless" ideas for the space include public galleries, street theatre, poetry readings, live music, and drumming and kite making workshops. Arts Deloraine members admit the site needs a lot of work before it can facilitate these events, requiring the removal of its concrete slabs, the introduction of new top soil, and connections to power and water utilities. Ms Middleton said the rear of the lot also needed to be levelled to make room for a stage. "It's our long-term strategy to actually purchase the land to keep it in the community," she said. "But at the moment, we're just trying to get it up to the point where we can utilise it properly." With the initiative costing a projected $63,200, Arts Deloraine has begun fundraising through a number of avenues, including trivia nights at the nearby British Hotel. It recently applied for a [$3000 community grant](https://www.examiner.com.au/story/8693527/meander-valley-council-sets-aside-30000-for-community-grants/) through the Meander Valley Council, but the request won't be approved until the group can "successfully secure funding for all the necessary base groundworks at the project site". Ms Middleton said this first stage of development could cost roughly $40,000 all on its own. "We're confident we will get the funding, but we're putting our fingers in many, many pies. Hopefully the thumb will come up right for us," she said. "So the vision's there, it's just organising the funding." The group will need to resubmit its grant application if it can't meet the council's conditions prior to December 10. Arts Deloraine president John Summers wants to keep the space "as simple as possible" for added flexibility. "If you add more and more infrastructure, then you reduce the opportunity for a lot of different things to happen," he said. "So we want to keep it as simple as possible so we can have a massive range of opportunities for people. "We just started, we don't even know all of the potential." Fellow committee member Zsuzsanna Handelsmann said the site was "open, but not useable" in its current state. "Urban pocket parks are in great demand all over the world. People just want a little space where they can sit down and meet other people," she said. "Apart from the footpaths, there is nowhere else to talk, unless you go in (to a business) and consume something." DAILY Today's top stories curated by our news team. Also includes evening update.
